body: “Unfairness bothers children greatly.” This quotation comes from Karen Joy Fowler’s 2014 novel We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves and it comes to mind on an almost daily basis as I struggle to manage the tensions between my two pre-teen boys. It is also a sentiment that appears to apply to meerkats, according to a nifty little study out today.  Meerkats live in groups, with a single dominant pair monopolizing reproduction. The non-reproductive individuals - other adults, a bunch of juveniles that may span several generations and a rabble of pups - must wait for the opportunity to breed. With age and body mass influencing a subordinate’s position in the queue for reproduction, it would make sense if individuals were sensitive to their own body weight and to that of their rivals.  The latest study to come out of the long-running, University of Cambridge-led Kalahari Meerkat Project explores this prediction with an experiment. Working with habituated meerkats in the Kuruman River Reserve on the outskirts of the Kalahari Desert, the zoologists identified same-sex littermates and gave the lighter individual – the “challenger” – a boost to its body mass by feeding it half a boiled egg twice a day for three months. At the halfway point, challengers had put on significantly more weight than age-matched control meerkats from other litters. The “challenged” meerkats were quick to respond, eating more and growing significantly faster than controls (though not as fast as their egg-fueled rivals). When the researchers analysed the data for the second half of the experiment, there was no longer a significant difference between the “challenged” meerkats and controls, “suggesting that challenged individuals may not be capable of sustaining accelerated growth over extended periods.” It seems likely that the experiment resulted in the challengers jostling the challenged meerkats behind them in the queue for reproduction. Profoundly unfair.      It’s a long, hard slog to become a dominant meerkat Photograph: Mattias Klum/Getty Images/National Geographic    Given this competition between subordinates to grow themselves to the head of the queue, the researchers asked what happens to body mass when an individual attains dominance. It shoots up, they found. This sudden increase was most pronounced when the next meerkat in line was of comparable size. The mechanism for this change is probably not down to food intake (which didn’t change much), but is “probably associated with the sudden lifting of reproductive suppression and a re-orientation of life-history strategy.”  I was one of the first volunteers on this project, now more than 20 years ago. Some of the data in this paper come from that time, testimony to the value of long-term field studies. The results, conclude Elise Huchard and her colleagues in this week’s Nature, “suggest that competitive growth may represent an important component of the developmental strategy of individuals.” It’s probably a phenomenon that occurs in other social species, they argue, “including domestic mammals, non-human primates and humans.” It certainly happens in my house.  Huchard, E. et al. Competitive growth in a cooperative mammal. Nature 10.1038/nature17986
webTitle: Compare the meerkat? Meerkats watch rivals’ growth and eat to compete
